markdown.headingText: The Anatomy of a Level 4 Travel Advisory: Safety, Economy, and Tourism
markdown.markdown:
Tourism plays an important role in a country’s economy, giving travelers the chance to explore new cultures and experiences while supporting local businesses. To help travelers make safer decisions, the U.S. Department of State ranks every country under one of four advisory levels: Level 1 (*Exercise Normal Precautions*), Level 2 (*Exercise Increased Caution*), Level 3 (*Reconsider Travel*), or Level 4 (*Do Not Travel*) ([Travel Advisories](https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/traveladvisories.html)). This project, **“The Anatomy of a Level 4 Travel Advisory: Safety, Economy, and Tourism,”** looks deeper into what drives a country to reach the highest level of warning. One factor that stands out is the death of U.S. citizens abroad which is a serious event that not only triggers formal action from consular officers but also weighs heavily in the State Department’s travel assessments. Using a mix of travel advisory data, U.S. citizen death records, global safety indexes, tourism trends, and economic indicators, this project explores not just why some countries are considered highly unsafe, but also what those warnings mean for their economies and their place in the world. :::{.cr-section} {{< spacer 10svh >}} @cr-map ### U.S.-Issued Travel Advisory Levels by Country (2023–2025) [@cr-map] This choropleth map provides a worldwide snapshot of travel advisories issued by the U.S. Department of State, based on the most recent updates between 2023 and 2025. The department advises travelers by categorizing countries into four levels of caution according to safety, political stability, crime rates, health risks, and other critical factors. While the majority of countries fall under Level 1 (green) and Level 2 (yellow) advisories, significant clusters of Level 3 (orange) and Level 4 (red) countries are visible across parts of Africa, the Middle East, Eastern Europe, and Latin America. ## Why the United States Is Not Listed in Its Own Travel Advisories The **United States ** [@cr-map]{pan-to="60%,-5%" scale-by="1.8"}is not ranked in this graph because the U.S. Department of State does not issue travel advisories for domestic destinations within the country. Its travel advisory system is specifically designed to inform U.S. citizens about potential risks when traveling abroad, not domestic travels. ([Travel Advisories](https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/traveladvisories.html)) ## Level 1: Exercise Normal Precautions Out of the four levels,[@cr-map]{pan-to="60%, 15%" scale-by="1.8"}countries in this category have received the lowest advisory level from the U.S. Department of State, advising travelers to exercise standard precautions. While these destinations are generally safe, it's still essential to remain vigilant, as conditions can change . ([Travel Safety Overview](https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/international-travel/before-you-go/about-our-new-products.html)). On June 6, 2024, Canada was reissued a Level 1 advisory, encouraging travelers to exercise normal precautions in what is considered a generally safe and stable environment ([Travel Safety Overview](https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/international-travel/before-you-go/about-our-new-products.html)). ## Level 2: Exercise Increased Caution Out of the four advisory levels,[@cr-map]{pan-to="60%, -15%" scale-by="1.8"} countries at this level have received the second level advisory level from the U.S. Department of State, indicating heightened risks to safety and security. Peru, for example, was designated a Level 2 advisory on November 15, 2023, urging travelers to exercise increased caution due to widespread crime, frequent civil unrest, and a heightened risk of kidnapping, especially in certain regions ([Travel Safety Overview](https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/international-travel/before-you-go/about-our-new-products.html), [Peru Travel Advisory](https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/international-travel/International-Travel-Country-Information-Pages/Peru.html)). ## Level 3: Reconsider Travel Out of the four advisory levels, [@cr-map]{pan-to="-20%,10%" scale-by="2.6"}countries at this level have received the third level advisory level from the U.S. Department of State, advising travelers to avoid non-essential travel due to serious risks, including widespread crime or health concerns. It's crucial to assess whether travel is necessary and to take additional precautions. On March 21, 2025, Niger was renewed at a Level 3 'Reconsider Travel' advisory due to elevated risks of violent crime, terrorism, kidnapping, civil unrest, and limited access to medical care, particularly near border regions ([Niger Travel Advisory](https://ne.usembassy.gov/republic-of-niger-level-3-reconsider-travel/)). ## Level 4: Do Not Travel Out of the four advisory levels, [@cr-map]{pan-to="-20%,40%" scale-by="2.6"} countries at this level have received the highest advisory level by the U.S. Department of State. They indicate a significant likelihood of life-threatening risks such as armed conflict or terrorism. The U.S. government may have limited ability to assist in emergencies in these areas. As of June 27, 2024, Russia was reissued a Level 4 'Do Not Travel' advisory due to the consequences of the full-scale invasion of Ukraine, widespread harassment and wrongful detention of U.S. citizens, restricted embassy support, and the persistent threat of terrorism and civil unrest ([Travel Safety Overview](https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/international-travel/before-you-go/about-our-new-products.html), [Russia Travel Advisory](https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/traveladvisories/russia-travel-advisory.html)). [@cr-map] :::{#cr-map .cr-visible style="min-height: 750px;"}
::: :::{#cr-mapped .cr-visible style="min-height: 700px;"}
::: ## U.S. Citizen Deaths and Level 4 Travel Warnings: A Regional Perspective [@cr-mapped] One of the main reasons for a country to be categorized as a Level 4 advisory is the occurrence of the death of a U.S. citizen overseas. When a U.S. citizen dies abroad, it triggers a formal intervention by U.S. consular officers, who are responsible for notifying next of kin, securing the deceased’s effects, and managing complex legal and logistical challenges ([Estates and Effects of Deceased U.S. Citizens](https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/international-travel/while-abroad/death-abroad1/estates-of-deceased-US-citizens.html)). To better understand this relationship, the bubble map below visualizes the regions where deaths have coincided with Level 4 advisories. Average deaths were calculated by aligning incidents that occurred within two years prior to a country's Level 4 designation, ensuring that the measure captures the period of instability leading up to the advisory. Deaths were then grouped by region and standardized to create a clearer comparison across the globe. ## Spotlight on the Americas The Americas [@cr-mapped]{pan-to="60%,-5%" scale-by="1.8"}stand out on the map not because of the number of Level 4 countries, but because of the concentrated safety risks within a few destinations. With only two countries, Haiti and Venezuela, under a Level 4 advisory, the region still shows the highest average of 3.8 U.S. citizen deaths per country over the two years leading up to each advisory. Europe and Asia follow closely behind, with averages of 3.4 and 3.2 deaths per country respectively during the same two-year period. These patterns suggest that even when only a few countries are classified as Level 4, the underlying risk to U.S. travelers can remain dangerously high across entire regions. :::{#cr-map2 .cr-visible style="min-height: 700px;"}
::: ## Third map [@cr-map2] Text :::{#cr-map3 .cr-visible style="min-height: 700px;"}
